Welcome!
This is a dissertation project on regenerative farming and wellbeing in Ireland.{br}{br}{b}** Important Information **{/b}{br}For this survey you will need as much screen space as possible!{br}{br}If necessary, please {b}MAXIMIZE{/b} the size of your browser window, {b}{i}reload{/i}{/b} this web page, and click on the "Continue" button to start the survey.

Introduction
{b}{i}{u}Do expectations meet reality? Using q-method to assess the role of and impact on 3D wellbeing in transitioning to regenerative agriculture amid farmers in Ireland.{/u}{/i}{/b} The aim of the project is to evaluate the role of and impact on three-dimensional wellbeing (subjective, material, relational) in farmers transitions to regenerative agriculture (an umbrella term for socio-ecological practices). Questions being considered are: {i}What aspects of wellbeing are farmers looking to improve? How does practicing regenerative agriculture impact wellbeing?{/i} The hypothesis is that subjective and relational aspects of human wellbeing (such as social networks, sense of responsibility etc) will have a considerable role in deciding to transition, suggesting the need for incentives to go beyond solely finances. The study will compare the wellbeing motivations/expectations (this Q sort) with the experienced wellbeing outcomes (second Q sort), identifying support gaps to better inform policy steering the agricultural transition, increasing effectiveness and adoption. This is a farmer centred holistic approach, recognising farmer wellbeing as an indicator of truly sustainable socioecological agriculture.
Step 1 of 5
Think about what factors had an influence in making the decision to change practices. Read the following statements carefully and split them up into three piles: a pile for statements that didn't influence/were of no importance in your decision, a pile for statements that did have an influence and were of importance, then a pile for the rest.{br}{br}You can either drag the cards into one of the three piles or {b}press 1, 2, 3{/b} on your keyboard. Changes can be made later.{br}{br}If you want to read this instruction a second time, press the help-button at the bottom left corner.
Step 2 of 5
Take the cards from the "MOST IMPORTANT"-pile and arrange them on right side of the score sheet.{br}{br}Next, take the cards from the "MOST UNIMPORTANT"-pile and arrange them on the left side of the score sheet. Follow this procedure for all cards in the "MOST IMPORTANT"- and "MOST UNIMPORTANT"-piles.{br}{br}Finally, take the "NEUTRAL"-cards arrange them in the remaining open boxes of the score sheet.
